data.title: Very high CPU + memory usage by "watcherService" service process + possible cause
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.1 64bit

There have been some (unresolved) reports about high CPU load: #14222 #10439

I'm experiencing a similar high load on Ubuntu. It's always the "--type=watcherService" process. It even happens with --extensions-disabled

top output:
```
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND     
29275 ivo       20   0 2546512 1,579g  33836 R 115,3 10,1   2:36.30 code  
```

ps output:
```
ivo      29275  115 10.1 2588532 1667120 ?     Rl   16:40   3:06 /usr/share/code/code /usr/share/code/resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=watcherService
```

When `strace`-ing the process I noticed the following output:

```
(lots of)
futex(0x7f7c4ef2c9e0, FUTEX_WAKE_PRIVATE, 1) = 1
futex(0x7f7c4ef2ca0c, FUTEX_WAKE_OP_PRIVATE, 1, 1, 0x7f7c4ef2ca08, {FUTEX_OP_SET, 0, FUTEX_OP_CMP_GT, 1}) = 1
futex(0x7f7c4ef2c9e0, FUTEX_WAKE_PRIVATE, 1) = 1
(and then)
inotify_add_watch(35, "/home/ivo/m3r/projects/Guts/viscera/tmp/broccoli_merge_trees-output_path-rsLThmVz.tmp/modules/ember-getowner-polyfill", IN_MODIFY|IN_ATTRIB|IN_MOVED_FROM|IN_MOVED_TO|IN_CREATE|IN_DELETE|IN_DELETE_SELF|IN_MOVE_SELF) = 68357
```

Specifically the `inotify_add_watch` on some file in tmp/ which was loaded with (old) files caught my attention. There's no need to watch these files and watching all of them could very well cause the problem.

After removing tmp/ entirely the problem disappeared. After filling tmp/ again with about 20 copies of itself (resulting in appr. 400.000 files), the problem reappeared. And after removing the issue is gone again.

This happens even with 

```
    "files.exclude": {
        "tmp/": true
    }
```

Conclusion: could it be the watcherService ignores `files.exclude` and tmp/ folders in general and will happily attempt to monitor 400K+ files?

data.title: getting two windows of the workbench after running tests
data.body:
(don't have hot exit enabled)
* run `scripts/code.sh` have only one window open
* run `scripts/test-integration`
* run `scripts/code.sh` again
* 🐛 it now opens two windows - the test workspace and the formerly used one

Actual:
Document is always formatted with 4 and editor.tabSize is ignored.

data.title: Enable "Find in selection" within single lines
data.body: Fixes (or implements? ;) ) Microsoft/vscode#15125

data.title: [Feature-request] File Explorer extensions API
data.body:
## Motivation
I was looking for extension that enables working with `node_modules` in way that looks like it done in Visual Studio:
![solution explorer](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15427508/20345514/c3ba8c8c-abf7-11e6-87d8-fc679412749b.png)
And I haven't found any. Then I investigated `vscode API` and realized that there is no way provided for extending File Explorer, so I can't create such extension also.
## What this feature offers?
This API could be useful for providing a way to restructure appearance of files and folders in File Explorer in order to organize it in more useful way depending on platform. It also could be used for extensions that change file appearance e.g. makes one folder-like group from `file.ts`, `file.js`, `file.d.ts`, `file.js.map`.
## Implementation ideas
I'm not very familiar with `vscode API` for now, but it seems that it could be reached by adding API for registering function that looks like this:
```TypeScript
TransformFolderStructure(structure: IFolderStructure): IFolderStructure
```
which would be called by vscode, when folder structure changed. And because of that this function has same return type as argument type, we are able to apply several transform functions, where each one uses result of previous. So in most cases different extensions that uses this API wouldn't conflict.
## P.S.
If this idea doesn't conflict with plans of vscode team, I would love to participate in its implementation.

data.title: Include newline when expanding line selection
data.body:
Fixes Microsoft/vscode#14485

A note for future reference: This PR leaves the current behaviour when selecting wrapped long lines intact / in the same state it is currently implemented (it handles wrapped lines as if they are real lines). 

Although I disagree with the current implementation – selecting a line should select the whole real line, because otherwise you semantically cut a real line in half – the way moving up/down in the editor treats those wrapped lines as real lines anyway, so the implementation is at least consistent.

If the day comes where this movement behaviour is changed, `expandLineSelection` should be changed as well to stay consistent.

data.title: Is it possible to define cursor position during autocompletion
data.body:
I'm making use of the method ```CompletionItemProvider.provideCompletionItems``` to provide autocompletion. 
Is it possible to define the position of the cursor when an item has been selected.

My plan is to automatically add brackets for functions and methods that are selected from the autocompletion list, once selected I'd like to place the cursor between the two brackets, as follows:  
```
xyz.doSomething()
```
cursor will be placed between the two brackets, so user can type in any additional arguments if necessary.

I've had a look at the ```additionalTextEdits``` and ```textEdit``` properties of the ```CompletionItem``` class. However I don't know whether this can be used to define the cursor position or not.

data.title: Include more performance details in telemetry on startup
data.body:
Currently we only log ONCE on startup:
* the time it takes from startup until the workbench is ready (viewlet and editors open)
* number of CPUs
* memory

In the future we would like to log more to find out about our performance issues on startup
* log startup for each opened window, not just the very first one
* distinguish between an initial start (no windows) and subsequent window open
* log if the window opens a workspace or not
* log if a screen reader is attached
* add more performance numbers
   * time it takes to start and load extensions (`onExtensionsReady`)
   * time it takes to start and load extensions (from initial startup till `onExtensionsReady`)
   * time it takes to load `workbench.main.js` and all dependent modules
   * time it takes to open the viewlet
   * time it takes to restore editors
   * time it takes to load the workbench (open viewlet, open workbench)
   * time when the window gets the `loadUrl()` call

@Microsoft/vscode asking for more input if someone has an idea what else we could log to find out more.

data.title: Layer breakers in our code
data.body: There is `https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/textmodelResolver/common/resolver.ts` with a dependency onto `import { IModel } from 'vs/editor/common/editorCommon';` which isn't legal. It should live in `editor/common/services`

data.title: Adopt latest Marketplace CDN changes
data.body:
The Marketplace extension query now returns two Asset URI’s: `assetUri` and `fallbackAssetUri`.

Asset downloads should work the following way:

- **VSIXPackage**
  1. Use `fallbackAssetUri` with the `redirect` param.
  2. Fallback to `fallbackAssetUri` without the `redirect` param.
- **Other assets**
  1. Use `assetUri` without the `redirect` param.
  2. Fallback to `fallbackAssetUri` without the `redirect` param.

data.title: getConfiguration fails regression test 1.7.1 -> 1.8
data.body:
It seems (I think it's probably this) https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/15007 has broken the use of `getConfiguration` with depth settings passed:

With no user settings at all (the default options):
```javascript
console.log("direct:", vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('search.exclude')['**/node_modules']);
console.log("indirect:", vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('search.exclude').get('**/node_modules'));
console.log("with parent:", vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('search').get('exclude')['**/node_modules']);
```
Under 1.8:
```
direct: undefined
indirect: undefined
with parent: true
```
Under 1.7.1:
```
direct: true
indirect: true
with parent: true
```

Causes: https://github.com/HookyQR/VSCodeBeautify/issues/70

I can't guarantee it's this change, but it looks to be the right area.

data.title: Emit first key chord when timeout or wrong second key chord

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. add new keyboard shortcut "; n"
2. press ";"
3. will wait for second key chord forever if I don't press any key
4. press a wrong second key chord, nothing happen

Expected:
1. at step 3 should have a timeout, when timeout the firset key ";" will input.
2. at step 4, if a wrong second key press, like "m", then the ";m" will input to the editor.

Just like Atom did.

I have made a bunch of tasks in my tasks.json file.

Current behavior-

Desired behavior -
I would like to replace the cmd-shift-b key-binding (or any key-binding of course) with jumping directly to the tasks pop up menu so I can pick one of many tasks.

data.title: Update watermark with commands relevant in context
data.body:
We should remove the editor commands from the watermark because these cannot be acted on at the time the watermark is shown. We also need to distinguish between the workbench being open on a folder or not, some commands make more sense in one case than the other. The following is a proposal for the (currently 5) commands in each case:

Commands in an empty workbench:
- Show All Commands
- Open File
- Open Folder (not on Mac where it is included in Open File)
- Open Recent
- New File (only on Mac)
- Toggle Terminal

Commands in a workbench opened on a folder:
- Show All Commands
- Go to File (QuickOpen)
- Search in Files
- Start Debugging
- Toggle Terminal

Another distinct context is that of the first session after installation where the user is looking for ways to explore and become comfortable with the workbench.

Commands in first session after install:
- Show All Commands
- Choose Theme
- Choose Keymap
- Open Folder
- Keyboard Cheatsheet

/cc @bpasero @joaomoreno @sandy081 @chrisdias @seanmcbreen @kieferrm @bgashler1 for feedback

Plan item: #15383

data.title: Hexadecimal integer match capitalized prefix `0x`
data.body:
The idea arose from the fact that I couldn't see `0XFF` highlighted as an integer when `0xFF` obviously did. 
As said in the [Golang's language specification](https://golang.org/ref/spec#Integer_literals), an hexadecimal integer literal should match either `0x` or `0X` as prefix i.e. `0[xX]` regexp.

This is a Pull Request to fix the Go's parser in VS Code.

data.title: Improve Typography of Markdown Preview
data.body:

- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Currently the text looks really cramped together and too light.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/20328749/46f0d50c-ab49-11e6-8658-d9cf57a3ef75.png)

Made a change to use `-apple-system` at 16px.

- Left: `-apple-system`, which is San Francisco. 16px.
- Right: `HelveticaNeue-Light`. What we are using. 14px.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/20328550/38251458-ab48-11e6-9329-150c15c0fbaa.png)

Maybe we should also add some `letter-spacing`.
.2px `letter-spacing`:
